content.description: The most eye catching route at Lizard Tail, Xenomorph is a great splitter. The majority of the route is cruiser 5.7/5.8. Hand jam, ringlock, finger jam and stem your way up to a exposed crux. When the crack starts to get a bit dirty near the top, move left and clip two bolts joining the hivemind atop the limestone band.
content.protection: Doubles from #.3-#1 camalot. Singles from #2-#4, bring two draws for the crux bolts.
content.location: The leftmost route at the center of lizard spire.

content.description: An uncleaned squeeze chimney that has some fun moves on suspect rock. The top section after the squeeze chimney has some seriously loose rock. Best set up as a toprope.
content.protection: Anchors for the climb are atop the limestone band 10 feet right of Xenomorph
content.location: To the right of King Gizzard

climbs.name: Rango
climbs.fa: Iain Macdonald, Andy Grieder Equip: John Knight/Iain Macdonald

content.description: Rango is located on the North side of Lizard Tail Spire and ascends the obvious splitter. Unlike other climbs on Lizard Tail this climb rarely see's sun. The climb starts on a fun but short face leading to big ledge. Climb through some easy 5.6 territory to get to the good stuff. The next portion is super rad, as you climb through an overhung .75 splitter. Finally, cruise up to a height dependent crux. This will either feel 5.8 or 5.10 if you can't find the hidden face hold out right. Depending on your reach clipping the chains will be the crux, fortunately there’s great gear through this last stretch. Overall this an awesome addition to Lizard Tail.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chains, singles from #.1 camalot to #3. I used doubles in .5, .75, 1 camalot
content.location: Located on the backside of Lizard Tail. It's fairly obvious when approaching from the southside. Pass under Karma Chameleon (climbers right) and walk 50 or so yards to the base on the north side.

content.description: This little spire makes for a fun adventure for a new trad leader or someone just getting into climbing. This might be one of the most accessible spires in Sedona. A couple of easy moves gets you a bit of exposure and a fun little summit. Look for a single bolt on the west side to protect the opening move that mantles a very fractured limestone shelf. I try not to step on the shelf at all just in case. After making the easy mantle, work your way up to the larger limestone band, then head up and right via exposed (but easy) climbing to a mushroom like summit. There are belay/rap chains on the highest point.
content.protection: 1 bolt plus a light rack of cams. Some people will be fine free soloing this climb.
content.location: From the Andante Trailhead, work your way up toward Chimney Rock. When you are at the high point of the hikers trail, head almost due north toward the spire. Should only take you 20 minutes or so from the parking area. The route starts on the west side and winds around the back (north) side to the summit.

climbs.name: King Gizzard And The Lizard Wizard
climbs.fa: FA: Iain Macdonald Equip: John Knight/Iain Macdonald

content.description: Arguably the most unique climb at Lizard tail and the Fun Ship area, King Gizzard is comprised of some funky climbing with two distinct cruxes. The first crux is pushing over the bulgy overhang on incut crimps, crafty crack climbing skills to the left can make these moves feel a bit more mellow. Weave left and right taking the path of least resistance to the final crux. The last moves involve some gymnastics style stretching, depending on your weakness this could be considered the hardest moves on the route.Funky, exposed and occasionally awkward, this route will test any 5.10 leaders in unexpected ways.

Much like a Chameleon, this route changes it's colors. This is possibly the best route at Lizard Tail, it's a fantastic climb with incredible positioning at a moderate grade. The climb is comprised into two separate sections.The first is a slabby sport climb while the second half is pure sedona trad route. There's handjams, crimpers, roofs, slabs, jugs, smears, and a secure layback. This climb may only be roughly 80 feet long, but it feels much longer. I'd recommend this route to any moderate leader, the gear is solid and the exposure is awesome.
content.protection: 6 bolts, Alpine draws, nuts and singles from #.3-#3 camalot. Doubles from #.5-#2. More experienced leaders can get by with a single rack.

climbs.name: Hippie Gecko
climbs.fa: John Knight, Iain Macdonald, Josh Kruse

content.description: Hippie Gecko ascends the slabby face below and just through the limestone band. The climbing is cruiser 5.7 to the band, followed by a few desperate 5.10 moves. This climb will test your commitment on slabby smears through a rounded bulge.
content.location: The leftmost bolted route on the lower tier

content.description: The little spire is just north of Chimney Rock in West Sedona/Capitol Butte (aka Thunder Mt.) area.Have you sent all the routes at the Fun Ship and need a new challenge? Check out the mixed bolted/trad routes at Lizard Tail. Note that only the front spire is "Lizard Tail Spire". The taller spires behind it have been referred to as Bart and Lisa. See pic taken from the east and you'll see why. There is a ton of potential routes up to and around these spires ranging from 5.8 to 5.11 (or higher). The rock quality varies from dirty/loose/flakey/rotten to bullet hard/clean. Stay tuned, more routes coming in this area. Send an e-mail via MP to me (John Knight) if you'd like to help out. Happy Climbing!
